title: 2 Malaysians rescued from Abu bandits
text:
2 Malaysians rescued from Abu bandits By Roel Pareño   Marines escort Tayudin Anjut and Abdul Rahim Bin Summas after they were rescued off the waters of Sulu yesterday in this photo provided by the Western Mindanao Command. 
ZAMBOANGA CITY – Two Malaysian sailors kidnapped by Abu Sayyaf bandits were rescued in Sulu yesterday after almost eight months in captivity. 
Members of the Marine Battalion Landing Team 1 special operations group and Navy men under Joint Task Force Sulu (JTFS) recovered Tayudin Anjut, 45, and Abdul Rahim Bin Summas, 62, near a mangrove in Barangay Karudong in Kalinggalang Caluang town at around 2 a.m., said Capt. Jo-Ann Petinglay, Western Mindanao Command (Westmincom) spokesperson. 
The two were among five Malaysians taken from a tugboat off the waters of Lahad Datu in Sabah on July 19. 
Maj. Gen. Carlito Galvez Jr., Westmincom chief, said the bandits abandoned their captives at the height of a military offensive. 
Galvez said they launched the operation after being tipped off that around 30 bandits led by Alhabsy Misaya are keeping the two Malaysians in the area. 
The victims were brought to a military hospital at Camp Teodulfo Bautista for checkup and treatment.   
“The victims are both weak and sick,” Galvez, said citing reports from Col. Cirilito Sobejana of JTFS. 
Military operations are ongoing to rescue the remaining hostages. The Abu Sayyaf is still holding 11 Vietnamese, a Dutch man, a Korean, seven Indonesians, three Malaysians and eight Filipinos. 4 crewmen seized 
Several hours after the Malaysians were rescued, unidentified men hijacked a cargo vessel and took four crewmembers off the waters of Basilan. 
Two of the victims were identified as Aurelio Agacac and Laurencio Tiro, captain and chief engineer, respectively, of Super Shuttle Ro-Ro 9 , a vessel of Panamanian registry. 
Lt. Cmdr Alvin Dagalea of the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) said the cargo ship was on its way to General Santos City when it was intercepted some 19 nautical miles southeast of Sibagu island at around noon. 
Dagalea said a PCG gunboat was deployed to secure the vessel while pursuit operations for the kidnappers are ongoing. 
There was no immediate report regarding the group responsible for the attack. – With Jaime Laude, Evelyn Macairan, Reuters
